text:
The **economy of Iceland** is small and subject to high volatility. In 2011,
the gross domestic product was US$12 billion, but by 2018 it had increased to
a nominal GDP of US$27 billion. With a population of 387,000, this is $55,000
per capita, based on purchasing power parity (PPP) estimates. The 2008–2011
Icelandic financial crisis produced a decline in GDP and employment, which has
since been reversed entirely by a recovery aided by a tourism boom starting in
2010. Tourism accounted for more than 10% of Iceland's GDP in 2017. After a
period of robust growth, Iceland's economy slowed down according to an
economic outlook for the years 2018–2020 published by Arion Research in April
of 2018.

Iceland has a mixed economy with high levels of free trade and government
intervention. However, government consumption is less than other Nordic
countries. Hydro-power is the primary source of home and industrial electrical
supply in Iceland.

In the 1990s Iceland undertook extensive free market reforms, which initially
produced strong economic growth. As a result, Iceland was rated as having one
of the world's highest levels of economic freedom as well as civil freedoms.
In 2007, Iceland topped the list of nations ranked by Human Development Index
and was one of the most egalitarian, according to the calculation provided by
the Gini coefficient.

From 2006 onwards, the economy faced problems of growing inflation and current
account deficits. Partly in response, and partly as a result of earlier
reforms, the financial system expanded rapidly before collapsing entirely in
the 2008–2011 Icelandic financial crisis. Iceland had to obtain emergency
funding from the International Monetary Fund and a range of European countries
in November 2008. The economy has since rebounded since 2010, and continues to
grow to this day.

Iceland bonds had an Inverted yield curve in 2008

10 year bonds

5 year bonds

2 year bonds
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Iceland is characterized as small and highly volatile, with significant fluctuations in economic indicators over time.
• In 2011, Iceland's gross domestic product (GDP) was valued at US$12 billion, reflecting the country's modest economic size.
• By 2018, Iceland's nominal GDP had increased to US$27 billion, indicating substantial economic growth over the seven-year period.
• The population of Iceland is approximately 387,000 residents, resulting in a per capita GDP of about US$55,000 when calculated based on purchasing power parity (PPP) estimates.
• The 2008–2011 Icelandic financial crisis led to a notable decline in GDP and employment levels; however, these economic indicators were fully recovered following a period of growth.
• The recovery was significantly driven by a tourism boom that began in 2010, which became a key sector for economic revitalization.
• In 2017, tourism contributed to more than 10% of Iceland's GDP, underscoring its importance to the national economy.
• Following a phase of robust economic growth, Iceland's economy experienced a slowdown, as projected in an economic outlook published by Arion Research in April 2018 covering the years 2018–2020.
• Iceland maintains a mixed economy characterized by high levels of free trade combined with government intervention in economic activities.
• Government consumption in Iceland is relatively lower compared to other Nordic countries, indicating a smaller role of government spending in the economy.
• Hydro-power is the primary source of electricity for both domestic use and industrial purposes in Iceland, highlighting the country's reliance on renewable energy sources.
• During the 1990s, Iceland implemented extensive free market reforms that initially resulted in strong economic growth and increased economic freedom.
• As a consequence of these reforms, Iceland was ranked among the countries with the highest levels of economic freedom globally and also enjoyed high civil liberties.
• In 2007, Iceland ranked at the top of the Human Development Index (HDI), reflecting high standards of health, education, and income.
• Iceland was recognized as one of the most egalitarian nations, with a low Gini coefficient indicating significant income equality.
• Starting in 2006, Iceland's economy faced challenges such as rising inflation and current account deficits, signaling economic instability.
• The financial system expanded rapidly in response to these issues and prior reforms but ultimately collapsed during the 2008–2011 Icelandic financial crisis.
• In November 2008, Iceland required emergency financial assistance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and several European countries to stabilize its economy.
• Since 2010, Iceland's economy has experienced a recovery and continued growth, demonstrating resilience post-crisis.

• In 2008, Iceland's bonds exhibited an inverted yield curve across various maturities, including 10-year, 5-year, and 2-year bonds, indicating market expectations of economic downturn or interest rate declines.

text:
In medieval Iceland, trade was traditionally conducted through barter. The
traditional nationalistic historical narrative says that Iceland had
experienced a golden age from 874 until the 11th century, when the country
came under foreign rule and "suffered humiliation" as its economy declined.
There is very little evidence to support this narrative.

Iceland had among the lowest GDP per capita out of all the Western European
countries at the start of the 20th century. An assessment by economists at the
Central Bank of Iceland stated that the country's "post-World War II economic
growth has been both significantly higher and more volatile than in other OECD
countries", and that "the Icelandic business cycle has been largely
independent of the business cycle in other industrialised countries." Iceland
has had a total of twenty financial crashes since 1875, according to Reuters.

Fishing became a large part of the Icelandic economy after the 1880s, partly
due to expanded fishing with sailing smacks. During the Second World War, the
UK imposed trade sanctions on Iceland to prevent them from trading with
Germany. After the British and later American occupations of the island, the
economy was boosted by a substantial amount, and Iceland went from one of the
poorest countries in Europe to one of the wealthiest. This was furthered by
Iceland being included as part of the post-WWII Marshall Plan, receiving the
largest amount per capita between 1948 and 1951, almost double the amount of
the next highest recipient.

Towards the end of the 20th century, Iceland's economy continued to grow. A
coalition between the Independence and Progressive parties led to the
privatization of state-owned banks and telecommunications. Corporate income
tax was reduced to 18%, inheritance tax was greatly reduced, and the net
wealth tax was completely abolished. The term "Nordic Tiger" became heavily
used refer to the period of economic prosperity in Iceland that began in the
1990s.

The "Nordic Tiger" period came to a sudden end as a result of the 2008
financial crisis. Iceland went from being the 10th richest country in the
world in 2007 to the 21st in 2010. Banks made risky loans and manipulated
markets, with the country's regulators understaffed and not properly
supervising them. The Icelandic króna underwent sharp inflation, with the
three largest banks in the country being placed under government control.
Iceland's central bank raised its interest rate to 18% in an attempt to combat
the inflation.

With help from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Iceland's economy
stabilized and managed to pay off all of its loans by the end of 2015.
Economists Ásgeir Jónsson and Hersir Sigurjónsson said that "Iceland was
treated differently from developing countries and former IMF clients. There
was no call for Iceland to adopt sharp austerity measures at the inception of
the joint economic plan. Instead, the government would be allowed to maintain
large public deficits in the first year – 2009 – allowing fiscal multipliers
to counteract the output contraction that was underway. Iceland also was not
asked to downsize its Scandinavian-type welfare system."
openai_summarised_points: • In medieval Iceland, trade was traditionally conducted through barter systems, reflecting early economic practices.

• The traditional nationalistic historical narrative claims Iceland experienced a golden age from 874 until the 11th century, characterized by prosperity, followed by foreign rule and economic decline, which supposedly caused "humiliation"; however, there is very little evidence supporting this narrative.
• At the start of the 20th century, Iceland had among the lowest GDP per capita compared to all Western European countries, indicating a relatively underdeveloped economy at that time.

• An assessment by economists at the Central Bank of Iceland noted that post-World War II economic growth was significantly higher and more volatile than in other OECD countries, with Iceland's business cycle largely independent of those in other industrialized nations.
• Since 1875, Iceland has experienced a total of twenty financial crashes, as reported by Reuters, highlighting ongoing financial instability.
• The Icelandic economy saw a significant shift after the 1880s with the expansion of fishing activities, particularly through the use of sailing smacks, which became a major economic sector.
• During World War II, the UK imposed trade sanctions on Iceland to prevent trade with Germany, which impacted Iceland’s economy.

• Following the British occupation and later American occupation during WWII, Iceland's economy was substantially boosted, transforming it from one of Europe's poorest countries to one of the wealthiest.

• Iceland was included in the post-WWII Marshall Plan, receiving the largest amount per capita between 1948 and 1951, nearly double the amount received by the next highest recipient, which significantly aided economic recovery.

• In the late 20th century, Iceland's economy continued to grow, driven by political coalitions such as between the Independence and Progressive parties, which led to privatization of state-owned banks and telecommunications.
• During this period, corporate income tax was reduced to 18%, inheritance tax was significantly lowered, and the net wealth tax was abolished entirely, fostering a more liberal economic environment.
• The economic prosperity experienced in Iceland during the 1990s was popularly termed the "Nordic Tiger," reflecting rapid growth and development.
• The "Nordic Tiger" period abruptly ended with the 2008 financial crisis, which caused Iceland to fall from the 10th to the 21st position in the global wealth ranking by 2010.

• The crisis involved risky loans and market manipulation by banks, with inadequate regulatory oversight, leading to sharp inflation of the Icelandic króna and the government placing the three largest banks under state control.
• In response to the crisis, Iceland’s central bank raised interest rates to 18% to combat inflation.
• With assistance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Iceland stabilized its economy and repaid all loans by the end of 2015.

• Economists Ásgeir Jónsson and Hersir Sigurjónsson noted that Iceland was treated differently from developing countries and other IMF clients, as it was not required to implement sharp austerity measures initially.

• Instead, Iceland was allowed to maintain large public deficits in 2009, enabling fiscal multipliers to counteract economic contraction, and was not asked to downsize its Scandinavian-style welfare system.

text:
Iceland occupies a land area of 103,000 square kilometers. It has a 4,790
kilometer coastline and a 200 nautical mile (370.4 km) exclusive economic zone
extending over 758,000 square kilometers of water. Approximately only 0.7% of
Iceland's surface area is arable, since the island's terrain is mostly
mountainous and volcanic.

Iceland has few proven mineral resources. In the past, deposits of sulphur
have been mined, and diatomite (skeletal algae) was extracted from Lake Mývatn
until recently. However, today most sulphur is obtained in the refining of
oil. The diatomite plant has closed for environmental reasons. The only
natural resource conversion in Iceland is the manufacture of cement. Concrete
is widely used as building material, including for all types of residential
housing.

By harnessing the abundant hydroelectric and geothermal power sources,
Iceland's renewable energy industry provides close to 85% of all the nation's
primary energy – proportionally more than any other country – with 99.9% of
Iceland's electricity being generated from renewables.

By far the largest of the many Icelandic hydroelectric power stations is
Kárahnjúkar Hydropower Plant (690 MW) in the area north of Vatnajökull. Other
stations include Búrfell (270 MW), Hrauneyjarfoss (210 MW), Sigalda (150 MW),
Blanda (150 MW), and more. Iceland has explored the feasibility of exporting
hydroelectric energy via submarine cable to mainland Europe and also actively
seeks to expand its power-intensive industries, including aluminium and ferro-
silicon smelting plants.
openai_summarised_points: • Iceland covers a land area of 103,000 square kilometers, making it a relatively large island nation in the North Atlantic.
• The country has a 4,790-kilometer-long coastline, providing extensive maritime access and influence.
• Iceland's exclusive economic zone (EEZ) extends 200 nautical miles (370.4 km) from its coast, covering an area of approximately 758,000 square kilometers of water.
• Only about 0.7% of Iceland's surface area is arable land, primarily due to the country's predominantly mountainous and volcanic terrain.
• The nation possesses few proven mineral resources; historically, deposits of sulphur have been mined, and diatomite (skeletal algae) was extracted from Lake Mývatn until recent times.
• Currently, most sulphur is obtained through the refining of oil, rather than direct mining.
• The diatomite extraction plant in Iceland has been closed for environmental reasons, indicating environmental considerations influence resource utilization.
• The only significant natural resource processing in Iceland is the manufacture of cement, with concrete being a widely used building material, including for all types of residential housing.

• Iceland harnesses abundant hydroelectric and geothermal energy sources, making its renewable energy industry account for approximately 85% of the country's total primary energy supply, which is higher proportionally than any other country.
• An impressive 99.9% of Iceland's electricity is generated from renewable sources, predominantly hydroelectric and geothermal power.
• The largest hydroelectric power station in Iceland is the Kárahnjúkar Hydropower Plant, with a capacity of 690 MW, located north of Vatnajökull.
• Other notable hydroelectric stations include Búrfell (270 MW), Hrauneyjarfoss (210 MW), Sigalda (150 MW), and Blanda (150 MW).
• Iceland has explored the feasibility of exporting hydroelectric energy via submarine cables to mainland Europe, aiming to leverage its renewable resources for international energy trade.
• The country actively seeks to expand its energy-intensive industries, including aluminium and ferro-silicon smelting plants, to capitalize on its abundant renewable energy resources.

text:
In 2017 the proportion of Iceland's exports was: tourism 42%, seafood 17%,
aluminium 16%, other 24%.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2017, Iceland's exports were distributed across several key sectors, reflecting the country's diverse economic activities.
• Tourism accounted for 42% of Iceland's total exports, making it the largest export sector in that year.
• The seafood industry contributed 17% to the nation's exports, highlighting Iceland's significant role as a major seafood exporter.
• Aluminium exports comprised 16% of total exports, indicating the importance of aluminium production and processing in Iceland's economy.
• The remaining 24% of exports consisted of various other goods and services, representing a diverse range of economic activities beyond the primary sectors listed.

text:
Tourism is Iceland's largest export sector by far. Tourism accounted for more
than 33% of the country's GDP in 2019. Iceland is one of the most tourism-
dependent countries on Earth. In October 2017 the tourism sector directly
employed around 26,800 people, with the total number of employees in the
country being 186,900.

At the start of the growth period around 2010, tourism benefited from a weak
ISK, but a strong ISK then cooled down the sector. From 2010 to 2018, tourist
arrivals in Iceland increased by 378%.
openai_summarised_points: • Tourism is Iceland's largest export sector by a significant margin.
• In 2019, tourism contributed to more than 33% of Iceland's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Iceland is considered one of the most tourism-dependent countries in the world.
• As of October 2017, the tourism sector directly employed approximately 26,800 individuals.
• The total employment in Iceland across all sectors was about 186,900 people in October 2017.
• The initial growth phase of Iceland's tourism industry began around 2010, benefiting from a weak Icelandic Krona (ISK).
• A subsequent strengthening of the ISK led to a cooling effect on the tourism sector.
• Between 2010 and 2018, the number of tourist arrivals in Iceland increased by 378%.

text:
Iceland is the world's largest electricity producer per capita. The presence
of abundant electrical power due to Iceland's geothermal and hydroelectric
energy sources has led to the growth of the manufacturing sector. Power-
intensive industries, which are the largest components of the manufacturing
sector, produce mainly for export. Manufactured products constituted 36% of
all merchandise exports, an increase from the 1997 figure of 22%. Power-
intensive products' share of merchandise exports is 21%, compared to 12% in
1997.
openai_summarised_points: • Iceland is the world's largest electricity producer per capita, benefiting from abundant electrical power generated primarily through geothermal and hydroelectric energy sources.
• The availability of extensive electrical power has significantly contributed to the growth of Iceland's manufacturing sector.
• The manufacturing sector in Iceland is predominantly composed of power-intensive industries, which primarily produce goods for export markets.
• Manufactured products accounted for 36% of Iceland's total merchandise exports, representing a substantial increase from 22% in 1997.
• Power-intensive products constitute 21% of Iceland's merchandise exports, up from 12% in 1997, indicating a notable expansion in this segment over the years.

text:
Aluminium smelting is the most important power-intensive industry in Iceland.
There are currently three plants in operation with a total capacity of over
850,000 metric tons per year (t/yr) in 2019, putting Iceland at 12th place
among aluminium-producing nations worldwide as of 2023.

Rio Tinto Alcan operates Iceland's first aluminium smelter (plant name: ISAL),
in Straumsvík, near the town of Hafnarfjörður. The plant has been in operation
since 1969. Its initial capacity was 33,000 metric tons (t) per year, but it
has since been expanded several times and now has a capacity of about 189,000
t/yr.

The second plant started production in 1998 and is operated by Norðurál, a
wholly owned subsidiary of U.S.-based Century Aluminum Company. It is located
in Grundartangi in Western Iceland near the town of Akranes. Its former
capacity was 220,000 t/yr but an expansion to 260,000 t/yr has already
finished. In 2012, the plant produced 280,000 metric tons which was valued at
610 million dollars or 76 billion krónur. 4,300 gigawatts hours were used in
the production that year, amounting to nearly one-fourth of all electrical
energy produced in the country. In October 2013, Norðurál announced the start
of a five-year project aimed at increasing its production by a further 50,000
t/yr.

United States–based aluminium manufacturer Alcoa runs a plant near the town of
Reyðarfjörður. The plant, known as _Fjardaál_ (or "aluminium of the fjords"),
has a capacity of 346,000 t/yr and was put into operation in April 2008. To
power the plant, Landsvirkjun built Kárahnjúkar, a 690-MW hydropower station.
The project was enormous in the context of the Icelandic economy, increasing
total installed electric power capacity from under 1,600 MW to around 2,300
MW.

Alcoa's aluminium plant in Reyðarfjörður, Iceland

According to Alcoa, construction of Fjardaál entailed no human displacement,
no impact on endangered species, and no danger to commercial fisheries; there
will also be no significant effect on reindeer, bird and seal populations.
However, the project drew considerable opposition from environmentalist groups
such as the World Wide Fund for Nature, which called on Alcoa to abandon the
plan to build Fjardaál. In addition, Icelandic singer Björk was a notable
early opponent to the plan; protesting the proposed construction, the singer's
mother, Hildur Rúna Hauksdóttir, went on a hunger strike in 2002.

Several other aluminium smelter projects have been planned. Between 2005 and
2011, Alcoa conducted a feasibility study for a second plant in Iceland near
Húsavík. That plant was to have a 250,000 t/yr capacity, to be powered
entirely by geothermal power, although later estimates showed a potential need
for other sources of power. In October 2011, Alcoa announced its decision to
cancel the Bakki project. In 2006, Nordurál signed a memorandum of
understanding with two Icelandic geothermal power producers, Hitaveita
Suðurnesja and Orkuveita Reykjavíkur, to purchase electricity for its own
aluminium reduction project in Helguvík. The power supplied will initially
support aluminium production of 150,000 t/yr, which will eventually grow to
support 250,000 t/yr.
openai_summarised_points: • Aluminium smelting is the most significant power-intensive industry in Iceland, playing a central role in the country's industrial sector.
• As of 2019, Iceland operates three aluminium smelting plants with a combined capacity exceeding 850,000 metric tons per year (t/yr).
• By 2023, Iceland ranks 12th globally among aluminium-producing nations based on its total production capacity.
• The first aluminium smelter in Iceland is operated by Rio Tinto Alcan, located in Straumsvík near Hafnarfjörður, known as ISAL.
• ISAL has been operational since 1969, initially with a capacity of 33,000 t/yr, and has undergone multiple expansions to reach approximately 189,000 t/yr.
• The second plant began production in 1998 and is operated by Norðurál, a wholly owned subsidiary of Century Aluminum Company based in the United States.
• Norðurál's plant is situated in Grundartangi, Western Iceland, near Akranes, with a former capacity of 220,000 t/yr, which was expanded to 260,000 t/yr.
• In 2012, Norðurál produced 280,000 metric tons of aluminium, valued at 610 million dollars or 76 billion krónur.
• The 2012 production consumed 4,300 gigawatt-hours of electricity, accounting for nearly 25% of Iceland's total electrical energy production that year.
• In October 2013, Norðurál announced a five-year project to increase its aluminium production capacity by an additional 50,000 t/yr.
• The third major plant is operated by Alcoa, an American aluminium manufacturer, near Reyðarfjörður, known as Fjardaál, with a capacity of 346,000 t/yr, commissioned in April 2008.

• The construction of Fjardaál involved the development of Kárahnjúkar, a 690-MW hydropower station built by Landsvirkjun, significantly increasing Iceland’s total installed electric power capacity from under 1,600 MW to approximately 2,300 MW.
• Alcoa reports that the construction of Fjardaál caused no displacement of humans, no impact on endangered species, and no threat to commercial fisheries, reindeer, birds, or seal populations.
• The project faced opposition from environmental groups such as the World Wide Fund for Nature, which urged Alcoa to abandon the project.
• Icelandic singer Björk was a prominent early opponent; her mother, Hildur Rúna Hauksdóttir, notably went on a hunger strike in 2002 protesting the construction.
• Between 2005 and 2011, Alcoa conducted a feasibility study for a second plant near Húsavík with a planned capacity of 250,000 t/yr, intended to be powered entirely by geothermal energy.
• Later estimates indicated that additional power sources might be necessary for the Húsavík project.
• In October 2011, Alcoa announced the cancellation of the Bakki project near Húsavík.

• In 2006, Norðurál signed a memorandum of understanding with Icelandic geothermal power producers Hitaveita Suðurnesja and Orkuveita Reykjavíkur to supply electricity for its aluminium reduction project in Helguvík.
• The Helguvík plant's initial capacity is planned at 150,000 t/yr, with potential expansion to 250,000 t/yr as the project develops.

text:
Fisheries and related sectors—in recent years labelled "the ocean cluster"—was
the single most important part of the Icelandic economy (it has now been
replaced by tourism) representing an overall contribution to GDP of 27.1% in
2011. The fisheries sector directly employs around 9,000 people (4,900 in
fishing and 4,100 in fish processing; approximately 5 per cent of Iceland's
workforce), although it is estimated that a total of between 25,000 and 35,000
people (up to 20 per cent of the workforce) depend on the ocean cluster for
their livelihood. Many of these jobs are provided by technological companies
that manufacture equipment for fisheries firms and by companies engaged in the
advanced processing of marine products or in biotechnical production. By
contrast, aquaculture remains a very small industry in Iceland, employing only
around 250 people for a production of 5,000 tonnes.

Iceland is the second biggest fisheries nation in the North East Atlantic
behind Norway, having overtaken the United Kingdom in the early 1990s. Since
2006, Icelandic fishing waters have yielded a total catch of between 1.1m and
1.4m tonnes of fish annually, although this is down from a peak of over 2m
tonnes in 2003.

Cod remains the most important species harvested by Icelandic fisheries, with
a total catch of 178,516 tonnes in 2010. The catch of cod has stagnated in
recent years due to quotas, and was supplemented by the catch of blue whiting,
which is used mainly for processing. The Icelandic catch of this previously
insignificant fish increased from a negligible 369 tonnes in 1995 to a peak of
501,505 tonnes in 2003. Subsequently, the stock showed signs of instability
and quotas were reduced, leading to a decline in the catch to 87,121 tonnes in
2010. There have been increased numbers of Atlantic mackerel (the "Miracle of
the Mackerel") in the 21st century as the Atlantic Ocean has slightly warmed.
openai_summarised_points: • The fisheries sector, historically known as "the ocean cluster," was the most significant component of the Icelandic economy, contributing 27.1% to GDP in 2011, but has since been surpassed by tourism in economic importance.

• The fisheries sector directly employs approximately 9,000 individuals, with around 4,900 working in fishing activities and 4,100 in fish processing, representing about 5% of Iceland's total workforce.

• An estimated total of between 25,000 and 35,000 people (up to 20% of the workforce) depend on the ocean cluster for their livelihoods, including jobs created by technological companies manufacturing equipment for fisheries and firms involved in advanced marine product processing and biotechnical production.
• Aquaculture in Iceland remains a small industry, employing roughly 250 people and producing about 5,000 tonnes of fish annually.
• Iceland is the second-largest fisheries nation in the North East Atlantic, ranking behind Norway, and overtook the United Kingdom in fisheries output during the early 1990s.
• Since 2006, Icelandic fishing waters have yielded an annual catch ranging from 1.1 million to 1.4 million tonnes of fish, a decline from a peak of over 2 million tonnes in 2003.
• Cod is the most significant species in Icelandic fisheries, with a total catch of 178,516 tonnes recorded in 2010.
• Cod catches have stagnated in recent years due to quota restrictions, and the catch has been supplemented by blue whiting, which is primarily used for processing.
• The catch of blue whiting increased dramatically from a negligible 369 tonnes in 1995 to a peak of 501,505 tonnes in 2003, making it a previously insignificant species in Icelandic fisheries.
• Following the peak, blue whiting stocks showed signs of instability, leading to quota reductions and a subsequent decline in catch to 87,121 tonnes in 2010.
• The Atlantic mackerel population has increased in the 21st century, a phenomenon referred to as the "Miracle of the Mackerel," attributed to the slight warming of the Atlantic Ocean.

text:
The Icelandic banking system has been completely overhauled after the 2008
financial crisis. There are now three major commercial banks: Landsbankinn
(National Bank since 2008), Arion Bank (formerly Kaupthing Bank) and
Islandsbanki (formerly Glitnir), and Kvika banki (formerly MP Straumur). There
are smaller banks and some savings banks, however they are not publicly
traded.

There has been extensive consolidation of smaller banks, with Sparisjodur
Keflavikur being taken over by Landsbanki and Byr being taken over by
Islandsbanki. Arion Bank, Islandsbanki, and Kvika Banki are the only banks
listed on Iceland Stock Exchange. Arion Bank is mostly owned by foreign
creditors while Landsbanki and Islandsbanki are now wholly owned by the State.
The ownership stake of the Icelandic State in the banks is managed by
Bankasysla rikisins (State Financial Investments), which aims to privatise its
shares in the banks in coming years.[_when?_]
openai_summarised_points: • The Icelandic banking system was completely overhauled following the 2008 financial crisis, resulting in significant structural reforms.
• Currently, there are three major commercial banks in Iceland: Landsbankinn (renamed the National Bank in 2008), Arion Bank (formerly Kaupthing Bank), and Islandsbanki (formerly Glitnir).
• In addition to the major banks, there are smaller banks and savings banks operating within Iceland; however, these smaller institutions are not publicly traded.
• Extensive consolidation has occurred among smaller banks, including the takeover of Sparisjodur Keflavikur by Landsbanki and the acquisition of Byr by Islandsbanki.
• Of the banks in Iceland, only Arion Bank, Islandsbanki, and Kvika Banki are listed on the Iceland Stock Exchange.
• Ownership structures vary among the major banks: Arion Bank is predominantly owned by foreign creditors, whereas Landsbanki and Islandsbanki are now wholly owned by the Icelandic State.
• The ownership stake of the Icelandic State in these banks is managed by Bankasysla rikisins (State Financial Investments), which is responsible for overseeing state holdings.
• The State Financial Investments agency aims to privatize its shares in the banks in the coming years, although specific timelines are not provided.

text:
Because of historically persistent inflation, historical reliance on fish
production and the long-standing public ownership of the commercial banks,
equity markets were slow to develop. Nasdaq Iceland, formerly the Iceland
Stock Exchange (XICE) was created in 1985. Trading in Icelandic T-Bonds began
in 1986 and trading in equities commenced in 1990. All domestic trading in
Icelandic stocks, bonds and mutual funds takes place on Nasdaq Iceland.

Nasdaq Iceland has used electronic trading systems since its creation. Since
2000, SAXESS, the joint trading system of the NOREX alliance, has been used.
There are currently two equities markets on Nasdaq Iceland. The Main Market is
the larger and better known of the two. The Alternative Market is a less
regulated over-the-counter market. Because of the small size of the market,
trading is illiquid in comparison with larger markets. A variety of firms
across all sectors of the Icelandic economy are listed on Nasdaq Iceland.

The most important stock market index was the OMX Iceland 15; however, this
index was discontinued after the 2008 financial crisis following a decade in
which it had been the worst-performing stock market index in the entire world,
being "more or less wiped out."
openai_summarised_points: • The development of Iceland's equity markets was historically slow due to persistent inflation, reliance on fish production, and the long-standing public ownership of commercial banks.
• Nasdaq Iceland, formerly known as the Iceland Stock Exchange (XICE), was established in 1985 to facilitate stock trading in the country.
• Trading in Icelandic Treasury Bonds (T-Bonds) commenced in 1986, marking the beginning of organized debt market activity.
• Equity trading in Iceland started in 1990, expanding the country's financial market activities.
• All domestic trading of Icelandic stocks, bonds, and mutual funds is conducted exclusively on Nasdaq Iceland.
• Since its inception, Nasdaq Iceland has employed electronic trading systems to facilitate market transactions.
• Since the year 2000, Nasdaq Iceland has utilized SAXESS, a trading system developed through the NOREX alliance, to operate its markets.
• Nasdaq Iceland features two equities markets: the Main Market, which is larger and more prominent, and the Alternative Market, a less regulated over-the-counter (OTC) market.
• Due to the small size of the Icelandic market, trading activity is relatively illiquid compared to larger international markets.
• A diverse range of firms from all sectors of the Icelandic economy are listed on Nasdaq Iceland, reflecting broad market participation.
• The primary stock market index was the OMX Iceland 15, which served as the benchmark for Icelandic equities.
• The OMX Iceland 15 index was discontinued after the 2008 financial crisis, which severely impacted the market.
• During its decade of existence, the OMX Iceland 15 was the worst-performing stock market index globally, effectively being "more or less wiped out" by the crisis.

text:
Historically, investors tended to be reluctant to hold Icelandic bonds because
of the persistence of high inflation and the volatility of the króna. What did
exist was largely limited to bonds offered by the central government. The bond
market on the ICEX has boomed since the 2010s, however, largely because of the
resale of mortgages as housing bonds.[_citation needed_]

A mutual fund market exists on the ICEX in theory, but no funds are currently
listed. A small derivatives market formerly existed, but was closed in 1999
because of illiquidity.[_citation needed_]

By the end of 2018, Bitcoin mining was expected to consume more electricity in
Iceland than all the country's residents combined.
openai_summarised_points: • Historically, investors in Icelandic bonds were reluctant due to persistent high inflation and volatility of the Icelandic króna.
• The available bond market was largely limited to bonds issued by the central government.
• The bond market on the Iceland Stock Exchange (ICEX) experienced significant growth since the 2010s, primarily driven by the resale of mortgages as housing bonds.
• A mutual fund market exists on the ICEX in theory; however, no mutual funds are currently listed on the exchange.
• A small derivatives market previously operated in Iceland but was closed in 1999 due to illiquidity issues.
• By the end of 2018, Bitcoin mining in Iceland was projected to consume more electricity than all the country's residents combined.
• The section on the economy of Iceland requires updating as of September 2024 to include recent events and newly available information.

text:
Iceland's economy is highly export-driven. Marine products account for the
majority of goods exports. Other important exports include aluminium, ferro-
silicon alloys, machinery and electronic equipment for the fishing industry,
software, woollen goods. Most of Iceland's exports go to the European Union
(EU) and European Free Trade Association (EFTA) countries, the United States,
and Japan. The 2020 value of Iceland's exports was $7.43 billion FOB.

The main imports are machinery and equipment, petroleum products, foodstuffs
and textiles. Cement is Iceland's most imported product. The total 2020 value
of imports was $7.55 billion. In 2019, Iceland's primary import partner was
Norway (11%), followed by the Netherlands (10%), Germany (8%), Denmark (8%),
United States (7%), United Kingdom (6%), PRC China (6%), and Sweden (5%). Most
agricultural products are subject to high tariffs; the import of some
products, such as uncooked meat, is greatly restricted for phyto-sanitary
reasons.

Iceland's relatively liberal trading policy has been strengthened by accession
to the European Economic Area in 1993 and by the Uruguay Round, which also
brought significantly improved market access for Iceland's exports,
particularly seafood products. However, the agricultural sector remains
heavily subsidized and protected; some tariffs range as high as 700%.

The fishing industry is one of the most important industries. It provides 40%
of export income and employs 7.0% of the workforce; therefore, the state of
the economy remains sensitive to world prices for fish products.

When corrected for the dramatic depreciation of the Icelandic króna in 2008
(approximately 50% against the euro and US dollar), imports since the 2007
peak have been negative.[_citation needed_]

| This article needs to be **updated**. Please help update this article to
reflect recent events or newly available information. _( February 2025)_
---|---
openai_summarised_points: • Iceland's economy is predominantly driven by exports, with marine products constituting the majority of goods exports.
• Other significant exports include aluminium, ferro-silicon alloys, machinery and electronic equipment used in the fishing industry, software, and woollen goods.
• In 2020, the total value of Iceland's exports was $7.43 billion FOB (Free on Board).
• The primary export destinations are the European Union (EU), European Free Trade Association (EFTA) countries, the United States, and Japan.
• Iceland's main imports consist of machinery and equipment, petroleum products, foodstuffs, and textiles, with cement being the most imported product.
• The total value of imports in 2020 was $7.55 billion.

• In 2019, Iceland's leading import partner was Norway, accounting for 11% of imports, followed by the Netherlands (10%), Germany (8%), Denmark (8%), the United States (7%), the United Kingdom (6%), the People's Republic of China (PRC) (6%), and Sweden (5%).
• Most agricultural products imported into Iceland face high tariffs; some imports, such as uncooked meat, are heavily restricted due to phytosanitary regulations.

• Iceland's relatively liberal trade policy has been reinforced through accession to the European Economic Area (EEA) in 1993 and participation in the Uruguay Round, which enhanced market access for Icelandic exports, especially seafood.
• Despite liberalization, the agricultural sector remains heavily subsidized and protected, with some tariffs reaching as high as 700%.

• The fishing industry is a critical sector, contributing approximately 40% of Iceland's export income and employing 7.0% of the workforce, making the economy sensitive to fluctuations in global fish prices.

• Following a significant depreciation of the Icelandic króna in 2008—approximately 50% against the euro and US dollar—imports since the 2007 peak have been negative, indicating a decline in import values.
• The article notes that the information requires updating to reflect recent events or new data, with the last update request noted as February 2025.
• The section provides detailed data on Iceland's import values measured in millions of Icelandic Krona (ISK) across the years from 1988 to 2012, including annual percentage changes.
• In 1988, Iceland's imports were valued at 68,723.2 million ISK, serving as the baseline with a 0.00% change from the previous year.
• Imports increased significantly in subsequent years, reaching 80,599.4 million ISK in 1989, representing a 17.28% rise.
• The upward trend continued in 1990 with imports at 96,620.7 million ISK, a 19.88% increase from 1989.
• In 1991, imports grew to 104,129.1 million ISK, a 7.77% increase, while in 1992, they slightly decreased to 96,895.3 million ISK, a 6.95% decline.
• The year 1993 saw imports decline further to 91,306.6 million ISK, a 5.77% decrease, but rebounded in 1994 to 102,541.3 million ISK, a 12.30% increase.
• The upward trend persisted with imports reaching 113,613.6 million ISK in 1995, a 10.80% rise, and then sharply increasing in 1996 to 135,994.5 million ISK, a 19.70% increase.
• In 1997, imports grew modestly to 143,226.6 million ISK, a 5.32% increase, followed by a significant jump in 1998 to 176,072.1 million ISK, a 22.93% rise.
• The growth slowed slightly in 1999 to 182,321.5 million ISK, a 3.55% increase, and continued in 2000 with imports at 203,222.1 million ISK, an 11.46% rise.
• In 2001, imports increased to 220,874.0 million ISK, an 8.69% rise, then decreased in 2002 to 207,607.5 million ISK, a 6.01% decline.
• In 2003, imports rose again to 216,525.1 million ISK, a 4.30% increase, followed by a substantial increase in 2004 to 260,430.8 million ISK, a 20.28% rise.
• The upward trend continued in 2005 with imports at 313,854.6 million ISK, a 20.51% increase, and in 2006 reaching 437,086.3 million ISK, a 39.26% surge.
• In 2007, imports slightly decreased to 429,468.9 million ISK, a 1.74% decline, but then increased again in 2008 to 514,739.3 million ISK, a 19.86% rise.
• In 2009, imports decreased to 446,128.2 million ISK, a 13.33% decline, then rose in 2010 to 477,222.3 million ISK, a 6.97% increase.
• The upward trend resumed in 2011 with imports at 561,626.1 million ISK, a 17.69% increase, and continued in 2012 to 597,262.2 million ISK, a 6.35% rise.
• The data is sourced from Statistics Iceland (statice.is), providing a comprehensive overview of Iceland's import values and their annual percentage changes over the specified period.
• The section provides a detailed overview of Iceland's export values from 1988 to 2012, measured in millions of Icelandic Krona (ISK), along with the annual percentage change.
• In 1988, Iceland's exports were valued at 61,600.0 million ISK, serving as the baseline with a 0.00% change from the previous year.

• Between 1989 and 1991, exports increased significantly: by 29.85% in 1989 to 80,071.7 million ISK, 15.68% in 1990 to 92,625.1 million ISK, and a slight decrease of 1.15% in 1991 to 91,560.4 million ISK.

• From 1992 to 1994, exports fluctuated with a modest decline of 4.07% in 1992 to 87,832.8 million ISK, followed by increases of 7.77% in 1993 to 94,657.6 million ISK and a substantial rise of 19.01% in 1994 to 112,653.8 million ISK.

• The period from 1995 to 1999 saw steady growth: 3.51% in 1995 (116,606.7 million ISK), 8.32% in 1996 (126,303.8 million ISK), 3.89% in 1997 (131,213.2 million ISK), 4.10% in 1998 (136,592.0 million ISK), and 6.10% in 1999 (144,928.1 million ISK).
• In 2000, exports increased by 3.00% to 149,272.8 million ISK.
• A significant surge occurred in 2001 with a 31.69% increase, reaching 196,582.2 million ISK.

• The growth trend continued with modest increases: 3.93% in 2002 (204,303.0 million ISK), a decline of 10.63% in 2003 (182,580.0 million ISK), and a recovery with a 10.84% rise in 2004 (202,373.0 million ISK).
• The years 2005 to 2007 experienced moderate growth: 3.96% in 2005 (194,355.3 million ISK), 24.90% in 2006 (242,740.0 million ISK), and 25.69% in 2007 (305,095.8 million ISK).
• The most notable increase occurred in 2008, with a 53.02% rise to 466,859.5 million ISK, marking a sharp growth phase.
• In 2009, exports grew by 7.28% to 500,854.5 million ISK, followed by a 12.02% increase in 2010 to 561,032.2 million ISK.
• The upward trend persisted in 2011 with a 10.53% increase to 620,127.4 million ISK, and a smaller growth of 2.08% in 2012 to 633,029.1 million ISK.
• Overall, Iceland's export values demonstrated periods of rapid growth, especially post-2000, with notable peaks in 2008 and 2011, reflecting significant shifts in export performance over the years.

text:
Iceland became a full European Free Trade Association member in 1970 and
entered into a free trade agreement with the European Community in 1973. Under
the agreement on a European Economic Area, effective January 1, 1994, there is
basically free cross-border movement of capital, labor, goods, and services
between Iceland, Norway, and the EU countries. However, many of Iceland's
political parties remain opposed to EU membership, primarily because of
Icelanders' concern about losing control over their fishing resources. Iceland
also has bilateral free trade agreements with several countries outside the
EEA. The most extensive of these is the Hoyvík Agreement between Iceland and
the Faroe Islands, this agreement goes even further than the EEA agreement by
establishing free trade in agricultural products between the nations. Iceland
has a free trade agreement with Mexico on November 27, 2000.

The currency of Iceland is the _króna_ (plural: _krónur_), issued exclusively
by the Central Bank of Iceland since the bank's founding in 1961. Iceland is
the least populous country to have its own currency and monetary policy.

Exchange rate for the krona to the euro from 2000 to mid-2010

During the 1970s the oil shocks (1973 and 1979 energy crisis) hit Iceland
hard. Inflation rose to 43% in 1974 and 59% in 1980, falling to 15% in 1987
but rising to 30% in 1988. Iceland experienced moderately strong GDP growth
(3% on average) from 1995 to 2004. Growth slowed between 2000 and 2002, but
the economy expanded by 4.3% in 2003 and grew by 6.2% in 2004. Growth in 2005
exceeded 6%. Inflation averaged merely 1.5% from 1993 to 1994, and only 1.7%
from 1994 to 1995. Inflation over 2006 topped at 8.6%, with a rate of 6.9% as
of January 2007. Standard & Poor's reduced their rating for Iceland to AA−
from A+ (long term) in December 2006, following a loosening of fiscal policy
by the Icelandic government ahead of the 2007 elections. Foreign debt rose to
more than five times the value of Iceland's GDP, and Iceland's Central Bank
raised short-term interest rates to nearly 15% in 2007. Due to the plunging
currency against the euro and dollar, in 2008 inflation was speculated to be
at 20-25%.

Inflation increased during the 2008–2011 Icelandic financial crisis, and the
Central Bank of Iceland pegged the krona's value to the euro at increasingly
higher and higher rates in an attempt to keep the currency stable, eventually
pegging it at 340 kronur per euro before all trade in the currency was
suspended. The krona similarly fell in value against the US dollar, going from
around 50–80 per dollar to about 110–115 per dollar. By November 2008, it had
continued to lower to 135 to the dollar. By early April 2009, the value
hovered around 119 per dollar, roughly maintaining that value over the next
two years. The currency has stabalized since the crisis, with 1 US$ being
worth 137.22 Icelandic kronur in September 2024.

Despite being heavily integrated into European Union via the European Economic
Area (EEA) and the Schengen Agreement, Iceland does not use the euro. Then-
Deputy Governor of the Central Bank of Iceland, Arnór Sighvatsson, said that
Iceland would not adopt the euro "as it entails extra cost of purchase of new
base money for the banking system and larger precautionary foreign exchange
reserves.

Iceland's economy had been diversifying into manufacturing and service
industries in the 1990s, and new developments in software production,
biotechnology, and financial services were taking place. The tourism sector
was also expanding, with the recent trends in ecotourism and whale watching.
However, in 2008, the Icelandic economy entered a deep recession during the
Great Recession. Although Iceland's economy grew 3.3% during the last quarter
of 2009, the overall contraction in GDP over 2009 was 6.5%, less than the 10%
originally forecasted by the IMF.
